case_name: Mohd. Yunus Saleem v. Shiv Kumar Shastri

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 282 of 1972 filed in Supreme Court from Allahabad High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 282 of 1972. From the judgment and order dated the 21st

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment and order dated 21st December 1971 in Election Petition No. 6 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and order dated the 21st December, 1971, of the Allahabad High Court in Election Petition No. 6 of 1971.

facts.text: Appellant Mohd. Yunus Saleem, defeated Congress R candidate, challenges election of Shiv Kumar Shastri (Respondent No.1, BKD candidate) to Lok Sabha from Aligarh Parliamentary constituency.

anchor.surface_text: by the appellant, Mohd. Yunus Saleem, the defeated Congress R candidate, is against the judgment of the Allahabad High Court wherein he challenges the election of the B.K.D. candidate, Shiv Kumar Shastri  Respondent No.1  to the,

facts.text: Aligarh Parliamentary constituency consists of five Assembly constituencies: 376-Aligarh, 377-Koil, 378-Iglas, 379-Khair, 380-Chandaus.

anchor.surface_text: Lok Sabha from the 76 Aligarh Parliamentary companystituency in the general elections held in March 1971. This companystituency companysists of five Assembly companystituencies namely, 376-Aligarh, 377-Koil, 378-Iglas, 379-Khair and 380- Chandaus.

facts.text: Seven candidates contested the election from Aligarh constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Mere were seven candidates on the-run for the election from this companystituency.

facts.text: Polling scheduled in Aligarh and Koil on March 1, 1971, and in Iglas, Khair and Chandaus on March 3, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The poll was scheduled. to take place in Aligarh and Koil on March 1, 1971. and in Iglas, Khair and Chandaus on March 3, 1971.

facts.text: Polling in Aligarh and Koil completed peacefully on March 1, 1971, with appellant obtaining highest votes.

anchor.surface_text: The polling. in Aligarh and Koil was companypleted peacefully on March 1, 1971 and the appellant obtained the highest number of votes as will appear from the chart given below

facts.text: Vote counts in each segment on March 1, 1971: detailed in chart, e.g., Mohd. Yunus Saleem 124,186 total.
Communal riot between Hindus and Muslims took place in Aligarh city on March 2, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On March 2, 1971 a companymunal riot between Hindus and Muslims took place in Aligarh city and as a result of this the Election Commission

facts.text: Election Commission postponed poll in remaining segments (Iglas, Khair, Chandaus) from March 3 to March 9, 1971 due to riot reports.

anchor.surface_text: the Election Commission on receipt of reports of the local authorities at Aligarh postponed the poll in the remaining segments from March 3, 1971 to March 9, 1971.

facts.text: On March 9, 1971 poll, Respondent No.1 Shiv Kumar Shastri obtained high percentage of votes and was declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: As will appear from the above chart, during the poll this time on March 9, 1971, the first respondent obtained a very high percentage of votes with the result that he was declared elected.

facts.text: Respondent No.2 Pooran Singh Malan was SSP candidate sponsored by four parties alliance.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd respondent, although a Samyukt Socialist Party candidate  SSP , was sponsored by the four parties alliance companysisting of Jan Sangh, Swatantra, Congress led by Shri Nijalingappa, and Samyukt Socialist Party.

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition alleging corrupt practices and questions of law; High Court repelled contentions.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleges several companyrupt practices in his election petition before the High Court and also raises certain question of law. ... The High Court has repelled the companytentions of the appellant

facts.text: Issue No.2: Petitioner alleged Election Commission's postponement order from March 3 to 9 was without jurisdiction; court held it valid under section 30 and General Clauses Act s.21.

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 2 Whether the order of the Election Commission adjourning the poll from 3rd March to 9th March was without jurisdiction and illegal ? ... There is, therefore, numbermerit in the companytention that the Election Commission had numberpower or jurisdiction

facts.text: Issue No.5: Petitioner alleged Pooran Singh Malan withdrew on March 6, 1971 due to inducements by Respondent No.1; court rejected for lack of reliable evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 5 Whether Pooran Singh Malan  respondent No. 2  withdrew from the election on 6th March and asked his supporters to vote instead for respondent No. 1. If so, was this done as a result of inducements offered at the instance of respondent No. 1 ?

facts.text: Election Commission notification dated January 27, 1971 fixed dates: nominations Feb 3, scrutiny Feb 4, withdrawal Feb 6, polls March 1-5, completion by March 15.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Commission published a numberification in the Gazette of India Extraordinary dated 27th January, 1971, fixing the following dates for the purpose of the election under section. 30 of the Act February 3, 1971-The last date for making numberinations.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Election Commission had power to alter poll dates under s.30 read with s.21 General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: Once this power is companyferred under section 30 upon the Election Commission, the power to amend the same, which will include alteration of the dates of poll, can be exercised under section 21 of the General Clauses Act.

facts.text: Issue No.7: Petitioner alleged Hukum Singh (polling agent of R1) induced voters by threats on March 7, 1971; court rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 7 Whether voters were induced by threats offered by Hukum Singh, the polling agent of respondent No. 1, to promise number to vote for the petitioner but to vote for respondent No. 1  as detailed in paragraph 28 of the petition  ?

facts.text: Issues 8,8A,9,10,11: Petitioner alleged appeals to vote on communal/caste grounds and false statements about riots at various meetings March 7-9, 1971; court rejected all for unreliable evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 8 Whether respondent No. 1 and Kalyan Singh, M. L.A. appealed to Hindu voters in Gordha village on 7-3-1971 number to vote for the petitioner because he was a Muslim  as detailed in para 29 of the petition  ... We, therefore, hold that Issues Nos. 8, 8A, 9, 10 and 1 1 are companyrectly decided by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld election, no corrupt practices proved.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: Whether even assuming gratification offered to Malan on 6th March 1971 to induce him to refrain from contesting amounts to corrupt practice under section 123(1)(A)(a) of the Act after expiry of withdrawal date under section 37

anchor.surface_text: Before we discuss the evidence, we may deal with a question of law addressed by Mr. Hardy, learned counsel for the contesting respondent. According to the learned counsel, even assuming that any gratification was offered to Malan on 6th March, 1971, to induce him to refrain front contesting the election, that would not amount to a, corrupt practice within the meaning of section 123(1)(A)(a) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant also submits that there should have been a fresh notification of the date in form No. 1 under rule 3, read with section 31 of the Act, of the Conduct of Elections Rules 1961.

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Withdraw' comprehensive to include retire from contest even post-legal withdrawal; purposive for purity of elections

arguments.claim: 'Withdraw from being a candidate' u/s 123(1)(A)(a) includes inducement to refrain from contesting even after s.37 withdrawal date

anchor.surface_text: When, therefore, section 123(1)(A) speaks of withdrawal from being a candidate, it is not limited to a candidate who has been validly nominated and who has withdrawn earlier according to law.

arguments.claim: Purity of elections requires broad interpretation of 'withdraw' in s.123(1)(A)(a) beyond legal withdrawal u/s 37

anchor.surface_text: Since purity of elections is the most important object of the Act, a narrow meaning to the word withdraw to refer only to legal withdrawal under section 37 would defeat the very aim.

arguments.claim: No corrupt practices u/s 123(1),(2),(3),(3A),(4) committed by R1

anchor.surface_text: We hold that no corrupt practice has been proved to have been committed by the first respondent under section 123(1), (2), (3), (3A) and (4) of the Act.

holdings.text: The Election Commission has power under section 30 of the Representation of the People Act read with section 21 of the General Clauses Act to amend the notification and alter the dates of poll.

anchor.surface_text: Once this power is conferred under section 30 upon the Election Commission, the power to amend the same, which will include alteration of the dates of poll, can be exercised under section 21 of the General Clauses Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power to issue notification under s.30 includes power to amend under GCA s.21; ss.57,58 apply to specific interruptions only.

holdings.text: Section 153 of the Representation of the People Act does not empower the Election Commission to alter dates of poll under s.30(d) as it only extends completion time under s.30(e).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the High Court that section 153 can be properly invoked in this case to the aid of the Election Commission in changing the dates of poll for the three remaining constituencies,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: s.153 amends s.30(e) completion date; alteration here within original completion period.

holdings.text: No fresh notification in Form No.1 under rule 3 r/w s.31 required for amendment of poll date.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant also submits that there should have been a fresh notification of the date in form No. 1 under rule 3, read with section 31 of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment engrafted into original notification via valid subsequent notification under s.30 + GCA s.21.

holdings.text: Offer of gratification to induce a candidate to withdraw or refrain from contesting after expiry of s.37 withdrawal period constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(1)(A)(a).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept the submission that even if the facts alleged be established, there can be no corrupt practice within the meaning of section 123(1)(A)(a) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: 'withdraw from being a candidate' comprehensive, includes retire from contest post-legal withdrawal to ensure purity of elections; deletion of 'retire from contest' not restrictive.

holdings.text: No corrupt practice of bribery under s.123(1)(A)(a) proved in inducement of Pooran Singh Malan to withdraw.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the High Court is wrong in not placing reliance upon his evidence. The High Court has also found the corroborating evidence equally unreliable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's witnesses unreliable (political turncoats, inconsistencies, improbabilities, lack of corroboration); Malan continued contesting and polled votes.

holdings.text: No undue influence under s.123(2) by threats from Hukum Singh to voters proved.

anchor.surface_text: We come to issue No. 7. This issue is with regard to the corrupt practice of undue influence under section 123(2) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's witnesses unreliable (supporters who turned, inconsistencies); rebutted by respondent's evidence.

holdings.text: No communal/caste appeals or false statements under s.123(3),(3A),(4) in meetings at Gordha, Iglas etc. proved.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that Issues Nos. 8, 8A, 9, 10 and 11 are correctly decided by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral testimony unreliable (party workers turned hostile post-election, no contemporaneous reports, discrepancies); rebutted by respondents.

holdings.text: Respondent No.1 committed no corrupt practices under clauses (1),(2),(3),(3A),(4) of s.123.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that no corrupt practice has been proved to have been committed by the first respondent under section 123(1), (2), (3), (3A) and (4) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All specific allegations fail for lack of strict proof; appellate interference requires convincing reasons to differ from trial court on oral evidence.

holdings.text: In election appeals u/s 116A, strict proof required for corrupt practices; appellate court must have convincing reasons to reverse trial court on oral testimony.

anchor.surface_text: In the matter of appreciation of oral testimony in an election dispute, this Court in an appeal under section 116A must have convincing and clinching reasons

holdings.reasoning_summary: High standard of proof in election petitions; not enough that another view possible.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; election of Respondent No.1 upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No merits in any issues raised; no corrupt practices proved.
